awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: The ability to tailor the optical properties of a material in ways that do not occur in nature has led to unprecedented control over the flow of light and an extraordinary range of technological opportunities. The goal of this research is to experimentally develop a new class of synthetic optical materials in which the means by which light is bent, absorbed, and amplified are varied independently of one another at the nanoscale. In particular, this work focuses on periodic spatial arrangements of these three properties, leading to unusual one-way effects for light propagation that may ultimately find application in future laser and optical circuit technologies. The themes of this research tie in closely with planned educational efforts involving course development for graduate and undergraduate students. In addition, outreach activities aim at increasing the exposure of k-12 students to optical science, technology, and the career opportunities they hold.

Technical description: This research identifies organic small molecules and polymers as a platform to experimentally realize parity-time (PT)-symmetric optical materials, and to explore the underlying physics and application possibilities that emerge from them. Organic materials are uniquely positioned for this purpose because they feature strong linear and nonlinear optical responses, they possess enormous synthetic freedom, and they can be mixed in arbitrary proportions and freely combined to form high optical quality films and microstructures.  This research will lead in the development of periodic PT materials and practical applications by focusing on PT materials with balanced gain and loss, PT materials incorporating low power nonlinearity, two-dimensional PT lattices, and PT systems in the strong coupling regime, where the relevant excitations are light-matter hybrids known as polaritons. Key results of this work include optical gratings that display unidirectional invisibility, thin film coatings with different forward and backward light transmission, and asymmetric polariton states that could provide a new path toward the long-standing goal of ultrafast, low power non-reciprocal optical functionality from non-magnetic materials.

por.por_cntn:
This program focused on exploring concepts in parity-time symmetry and strong light-matter coupling using organic small molecules and polymers as a platform. Through this work, we uncovered a new class of charged polariton (a hybrid light-matter quasi-particle) in organic semiconductors that could enable new electro-optic capabilities to manipulate the motion of polariton states directly with electric fields. As part of this work, we focused on understanding the nature of charged polariton electrical transport and how it can be used to evaluate the impact of strong light-matter coupling on the rate of photoinduced electron transfer between molecules. We identified the first experimental evidence of cavity-modified charge transfer and proposed a mechanism to explain this phenomenon based on polariton delocalization. We also showed that strong coupling can be used to manipulate optical nonlinearity from organic microcavities by engineering the energy of polariton modes relative to other states in the system, but that it does not alter the intrinsic nonlinear response of the organic semiconductor inside the cavity. Lastly, we advanced the field of non-Hermitian optics by showing that a judicious amount of loss added to magneto-optic isolators can create an exceptional point degeneracy that fundamentally increases their isolation bandwidth.

More broadly, the charged polariton species discovered in this research could enable new electro-optic capabilities to manipulate light directly with electric fields, which is important for a variety of optical communications, sensing, and information processing applications. The understanding gained about how strong light-matter coupling influences photoinduced electron transfer may open up new opportunities to control chemical reactions by tailoring their optical environment, and our development of non-Hermitian magneto-optics is significant for integrated photonics because it provides a path to achieve higher performance on-chip isolation for photonic integrated circuits. Beyond its research impact, this project supported the education and training of multiple graduate and undergraduate students, provided opportunities for their professional development at scientific conferences, and included outreach to middle school teachers that helped develop new, optics-related activities to implement in their classrooms.
